review.title: Spatial Symmetry Driven Pruning Strategies for Efficient Declarative Spatial Reasoning
review.abstract: Declarative spatial reasoning denotes the ability to (declaratively) specify and solve real-world problems related to geometric and qualitative spatial representation and reasoning within standard knowledge representation and reasoning (KR) based methods (e.g., logic programming and derivatives). One approach for encoding the semantics of spatial relations within a declarative programming framework is by systems of polynomial constraints. However, solving such constraints is computationally intractable in general (i.e. the theory of real-closed fields).

sections.text: Declarative spatial reasoning refers to the ability of declarative programming frameworks in AI to treat spatial objects and the spatial relations between them as native entities, as is possible, for example, in concrete areas of integer, real, and inequality relationships. sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: Affine transformations provide an effective and interesting class of symmetries that can be used to intersect a range of qualitative spatial relationships. In summary, we formalize the following as modular common sense rules in CLP (QS): point coincidence, line parallelism, topological and mereological relationships are retained in all affinity transformations; relative orientation changes in reflection and qualitative distances and calculation angle changes in uneven scaling; spheres, circles and rectangles are not retained in uneven scaling, except for axis-aligned boundary fields; our algorithm is easy to implement and expand to cope with more pressure cases; theoretical and empirical results show that our method of printing results improves performance by orders of magnitude over standard polynomic coding, without expanding the horizon of printing problems that are unsolvable in real-world situations.

metadata.abstractText: Declarative spatial reasoning denotes the ability to (declaratively) specify and solve real-world problems related to geometric and qualitative spatial representation and reasoning within standard knowledge representation and reasoning (KR) based methods (e.g., logic programming and derivatives). One approach for encoding the semantics of spatial relations within a declarative programming framework is by systems of polynomial constraints. However, solving such constraints is computationally intractable in general (i.e. the theory of real-closed fields). We present a new algorithm, implemented within the declarative spatial reasoning system CLP(QS), that drastically improves the performance of deciding the consistency of spatial constraint graphs over conventional polynomial encodings. We develop pruning strategies founded on spatial symmetries that form equivalence classes (based on affine transformations) at the qualitative spatial level. Moreover, pruning strategies are themselves formalised as knowledge about the properties of space and spatial symmetries. We evaluate our algorithm using a range of benchmarks in the class of contact problems, and proofs in mereology and geometry. The empirical results show that CLP(QS) with knowledgebased spatial pruning outperforms conventional polynomial encodings by orders of magnitude, and can thus be applied to problems that are otherwise unsolvable in practice.
